unit_learning_outcomes.description: Interpret the results of analyses using machine learning in light of the assumptions required, the quality of input data, and the sensitivity to the specific technique implemented
Effectively communicate results of analyses in language suitable for a clinical or epidemiological journal
Recognise situations where machine learning methods can offer advantages over traditional statistical modelling approaches to data analyses in health applications
Determine and implement appropriate machine learning approaches for description and prediction in real-world health applications
Recognise and explain the differences between the goals of description and prediction
Critically appraise published papers concerning machine learning applications for classification or prediction in health
Measure and explain the uncertainty of the results of analyses using machine learning approaches

enrolment_rules.description: (Admission to MBioStat or GradCertBioStat) and (STAT8609 or BCA808)

assessments.description: Short exercises [equivalent to 500-1000 words] with either mathematical derivations, explanation of concepts, data analyses.

Exercises requiring selecting an approach to a health application, determination and application of appropriate methods, interpreting and presenting results in suitable lay scientific language
Equivalent to 2000 words of text
[Covers Modules 1-3]

Exercises requiring selecting an approach to a health application, determination and application of appropriate methods, critical appraisal, interpreting and presenting results in suitable lay scientific language
Equivalent to 2000 words of text
 [Focusses on Module 4-6]

data.description: Recent years have brought a rapid growth in the amount and complexity of health data captured. Among others, data collected in imaging, genomic, health registries and personal devices call for new statistical techniques in both predictive and descriptive learning. Machine learning algorithms for classification and prediction complement classical statistical tools in the analysis of these data. This unit will cover modern machine learning methods particularly useful for large and complex data. Topics include, classification trees, random forests, model selection, lasso, bootstrapping, cross-validation, generalized additive modelling, and regression splines. The statistical software R package will be used throughout the unit.
data.title: Machine Learning for Biostatistics
